info.title: Dynamic Objects Service REST API
info.description: The REST API for the Dynamic Objects Service. There is also the Dynamic Objects Service GraphQL API.

parameters.name: fileId
parameters.description: The `LongNumberString` scalar type is a string representation of a number. The type represents non-fractional signed whole numeric values. It can represent values between `-9223372036854775808` and `9223372036854775807`. Example: `"1234567891234"`

parameters.name: from
parameters.description: The `DateTimeWithMicroseconds` scalar represents an ISO-8601 compliant date time type with microsecond precision. Please note that values without offset are assumed to be UTC, not local. So values ending with 'Z' and without offset are both assumed to be UTC. Example: `"2024-03-27T12:34:56.654321+02:00"`

schema.description: The `DateTimeWithMicroseconds` scalar represents an ISO-8601 compliant date time type with microsecond precision. Please note that values without offset are assumed to be UTC, not local. So values ending with 'Z' and without offset are both assumed to be UTC. Example: `"2024-03-27T12:34:56.654321+02:00"`

parameters.name: to
parameters.description: The `DateTimeWithMicroseconds` scalar represents an ISO-8601 compliant date time type with microsecond precision. Please note that values without offset are assumed to be UTC, not local. So values ending with 'Z' and without offset are both assumed to be UTC. Example: `"2024-03-27T12:34:56.654321+02:00"`

schema.description: The `DateTimeWithMicroseconds` scalar represents an ISO-8601 compliant date time type with microsecond precision. Please note that values without offset are assumed to be UTC, not local. So values ending with 'Z' and without offset are both assumed to be UTC. Example: `"2024-03-27T12:34:56.654321+02:00"`

parameters.name: auditTime
parameters.description: The `DateTimeWithMicroseconds` scalar represents an ISO-8601 compliant date time type with microsecond precision. Please note that values without offset are assumed to be UTC, not local. So values ending with 'Z' and without offset are both assumed to be UTC. Example: `"2024-03-27T12:34:56.654321+02:00"`

schema.description: The `DateTimeWithMicroseconds` scalar represents an ISO-8601 compliant date time type with microsecond precision. Please note that values without offset are assumed to be UTC, not local. So values ending with 'Z' and without offset are both assumed to be UTC. Example: `"2024-03-27T12:34:56.654321+02:00"`

parameters.name: auditExactlyAt
parameters.description: Determines whether the audit time should be applied exactly at the specified time or whether the latest audit time before the specified time should be applied. When `true`, only data with the exact specified audit time will be returned. When `false`, data will be returned for the latest audit time before the specified time.

schema.description: Determines whether the audit time should be applied exactly at the specified time or whether the latest audit time before the specified time should be applied. When `true`, only data with the exact specified audit time will be returned. When `false`, data will be returned for the latest audit time before the specified time.

parameters.name: quotationTime
parameters.description: The `DateTimeWithMicroseconds` scalar represents an ISO-8601 compliant date time type with microsecond precision. Please note that values without offset are assumed to be UTC, not local. So values ending with 'Z' and without offset are both assumed to be UTC. Example: `"2024-03-27T12:34:56.654321+02:00"`

schema.description: The `DateTimeWithMicroseconds` scalar represents an ISO-8601 compliant date time type with microsecond precision. Please note that values without offset are assumed to be UTC, not local. So values ending with 'Z' and without offset are both assumed to be UTC. Example: `"2024-03-27T12:34:56.654321+02:00"`

parameters.name: quotationExactlyAt
parameters.description: Determines whether the quotation time should be applied exactly at the specified time or whether the latest quotation time before the specified time should be applied. When `true`, only data with the exact specified quotation time will be returned. When `false`, data will be returned according to the latest time determined by 'quotationBehaviour'.

schema.description: Determines whether the quotation time should be applied exactly at the specified time or whether the latest quotation time before the specified time should be applied. When `true`, only data with the exact specified quotation time will be returned. When `false`, data will be returned according to the latest time determined by 'quotationBehaviour'.

parameters.name: quotationBehavior
parameters.description:
The quotation behaviour to apply. When `null` the default quotation behaviour of the time series will be applied.
* `LATEST_EXACTLY_AT` - The highest quotation date in the time range is determined and only the data for this date is read out.
* `LATEST` - The data in the time range with the highest quotation date is read out
* `LATEST_NO_FUTURE` - The data in the time range with the highest quotation date, but less than the current time, is read out

parameters.name: excludeQualities
parameters.description: The qualities to exclude. When `null` no qualities will be excluded.

schema.description: The qualities to exclude. When `null` no qualities will be excluded.

parameters.name: fileId
parameters.description: The `LongNumberString` scalar type is a string representation of a number. The type represents non-fractional signed whole numeric values. It can represent values between `-9223372036854775808` and `9223372036854775807`. Example: `"1234567891234"`

schema.description: The `LongNumberString` scalar type is a string representation of a number. The type represents non-fractional signed whole numeric values. It can represent values between `-9223372036854775808` and `9223372036854775807`. Example: `"1234567891234"`

files.description: Files must be uploaded as file sections of a multipart form data content. Each file section must contain a 'filename' (the original file name, e.g. 'my-file.pdf'), a 'content-type' (MIME type, e.g. 'application/pdf'), and a 'name' that contains the optional namespace name, the inventory name and the property name, separated by dots ('.'), for which the file is being uploaded (e.g. 'MyInventory.MyProperty', 'MyNamespace.MyInventory.MyProperty').

parameters.name: timeSeriesIds
parameters.description: The IDs of the time series for which data to retrieve

items.description: The `LongNumberString` scalar type is a string representation of a number. The type represents non-fractional signed whole numeric values. It can represent values between `-9223372036854775808` and `9223372036854775807`. Example: `"1234567891234"`

schema.description: The IDs of the time series for which data to retrieve

parameters.description: The `DateTimeWithMicroseconds` scalar represents an ISO-8601 compliant date time type with microsecond precision. Please note that values without offset are assumed to be UTC, not local. So values ending with 'Z' and without offset are both assumed to be UTC. Example: `"2024-03-27T12:34:56.654321+02:00"`

parameters.name: timeUnit
parameters.description:
The time unit of the interval to apply. You must specify 'timeUnit' and 'multiplier' together. When `null` the time unit of the time series will be applied.
* `SECOND`
* `MINUTE`
* `HOUR`
* `DAY`
* `WEEK`
* `MONTH`
* `QUARTER`
* `YEAR`

parameters.name: multiplier
parameters.description: The `IntNumberString` scalar type is a string representation of a number. The type represents non-fractional signed whole numeric values. It can represent values between `-2147483648` and `2147483647`. Example: `"1234567"`

schema.description: The `IntNumberString` scalar type is a string representation of a number. The type represents non-fractional signed whole numeric values. It can represent values between `-2147483648` and `2147483647`. Example: `"1234567"`

parameters.name: aggregation
parameters.description:
The aggregation to apply. When `null` the default aggregation of the time series will be applied.
* `SUM`
* `AVERAGE`
* `MIN`
* `MAX`
* `MOST_FREQUENTLY`
* `ABS_MIN`
* `ABS_MAX`
* `FIRST_VALUE`
* `LAST_VALUE`

parameters.name: unit
parameters.description: The unit to convert the values to. When `null` the unit of the time series will be applied.

schema.description: The unit to convert the values to. When `null` the unit of the time series will be applied.

parameters.name: timeZone
parameters.description: The time zone to use for the output. When `null` the time zone of the time series will be applied. Please note that the intervals for the time series data will always be determined by the start time and the interval of the time series. So the time zone is only relevant for the output of the time series data.

schema.description: The time zone to use for the output. When `null` the time zone of the time series will be applied. Please note that the intervals for the time series data will always be determined by the start time and the interval of the time series. So the time zone is only relevant for the output of the time series data.

QuotationBehavior.description:
* `LATEST_EXACTLY_AT` - The highest quotation date in the time range is determined and only the data for this date is read out.
* `LATEST` - The data in the time range with the highest quotation date is read out
* `LATEST_NO_FUTURE` - The data in the time range with the highest quotation date, but less than the current time, is read out

Please note that values without offset are assumed to be UTC, not local. So values ending with 'Z' and without offset are both assumed to be UTC. Example: `"2024-03-27T12:34:56.654321+02:00"`

Please note that values without offset are assumed to be UTC, not local. So values ending with 'Z' and without offset are both assumed to be UTC. Example: `"2024-03-27T12:34:56.654321+02:00"`

time.description: The `DateTimeWithMicroseconds` scalar represents an ISO-8601 compliant date time type with microsecond precision. Please note that values without offset are assumed to be UTC, not local. So values ending with 'Z' and without offset are both assumed to be UTC. Example: `"2024-03-27T12:34:56.654321+02:00"`

value.description: The `DoubleNumberString` scalar type is a string representation of a number. The type represents a fractional floating point numeric value. It complies with the IEC 60559:1989 (IEEE 754) standard for binary floating-point arithmetic. It can represent values between `-1.79769313486232e308` and `1.79769313486232e308`. Example: `"123456.1234"`

ValueAlignment.description:
* `LEFT` - When writing time series values, align the time to the left-hand side (beginning) of the interval. Example: For a time series with interval '15 MINUTE' the time '2025-01-01T12:02:34.457363' will become '2025-01-01T12:00:00.000000'.
* `RIGHT` - When writing time series values, align the time to the right-hand side (end) of the interval. Example: For a time series with interval '15 MINUTE' the time '2025-01-01T12:14:34.457363' will become '2025-01-01T12:15:00.000000'.
* `NONE` - When writing time series values, do not align the time to interval. The value will be split and written to the beginning and end of the interval, unless it is written exactly at the beginning/end of an interval.

ValueAvailability.description:
* `AT_INTERVAL_BEGIN` - For time series in which the values are available at the beginning of the respective measurement period (interval), e. g. power values (watts), temperature, wind speed or length.
* `AT_INTERVAL_END` - For time series in which the values are available at the end of the respective measurement period (interval), e. g. energy values (watt hour).
